text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
6 Minute English
speaker: Neil

text: from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Welcome to 6 Minute English, where we bring you an interesting topic and six items of vocabulary.
And all in just six minutes, of course. I'm Catherine.
And I'm Neil. Today is technology built to fail.
speaker: Neil

text: And are we throwing away too much technology and harming the planet?
Catherine, tell me how old is your TV?
My TV has just had its fifth birthday.
And your mobile phone?
speaker: Neil

text: It's about two and a half.
So you do like to have gizmos, but not necessarily the latest.
speaker: gizmos

text: Exactly.
Gizmo â€“ nice word. A gizmo is a small piece of technology
speaker: Gizmogizmo

text: otherwise called a gadget.
And of course, I'm not alone in buying gadgets from time to time.
They actually keep on getting more advanced,
so people keep buying new ones.
Technology also gets cheaper and cheaper.
speaker: Neil

text: In fact, many gadgets are more expensive to fix than replace.
And this means that we throw a lot of gadgets away, but how many?
See if you can guess: how much electronic waste is thrown away every year globally
speaker: Neil

text: Is it A, 420 tonnes, B, 4.2 million tonnes, or C, 42 million tonnes?
And I do actually know the answer to this one,
so I'm going to keep quiet just for once.
Ah, first time for everything.
speaker: Catherine

text: So to bring us back to our main point,
is technology no longer built to last?
Let's hear first from Professor Tim Cooper,
who's an expert in sustainable consumption and production
at Nottingham Trent University in the UK.
Sustainable, by the way, means 'able to continue over a long period of time
speaker: Sustainable

text: We often use it to mean able to continue without causing harm,
like environmental damage.
What's the problem with mobile phones?
A classic example of this is the mobile phone,
where, for example, screens are glued into the product.
Now they know that if there was a screw,
their consumer could easily win a screen crack,
which is obviously a very common problem with mobile phones,
unscrew and put a new screen on.
They don't. They know, perfectly well,
that that would be a way in which mobile phones would last longer.
They don't want that. They want you to replace your mobile phone every year or two.
Professor Cooper says that mobile phones' screens crack often
speaker: Neil

text: and generally, when that happens, people buy a new one.
That's partly because mobile phones screens are glued on,
rather than screwed on.
Now a screw is a piece of metal, like a nail,
but with a raised twisted part,
and we use screws to join two things together.
The verb form is the same to screw,
speaker: screwunscrewunscrew

text: and the opposite is to unscrew.
If you could unscrew a cracked screen and then replace it,
there'd be no need to buy a whole new phone, he says.
He thinks that generally, people have lowered their expectations
when it comes to how long things should last.
Expectations is a good word
speaker: ExpectationsexpectationExpectationslowered

text: and expectation is a strong belief something will happen.
Expectations can be raised or lowered.
Or managed. To manage your expectations
means to not let your expectations get so high
that you then become disappointed when something fails.
Yes, by way of an example, Professor Cooper says
speaker: Neil

text: that his parents washing machine lasted for 37 years.
These days, they last between five and ten.
Yeah, and we don't see electrical products
as an investment in the same way that people used to.
We now worry that what we buy today
will become obsolete tomorrow.
Obsolete â€“ no longer valid or useful
speaker: Obsolete

text: And also, he says we've become so used to cheap products
that we don't want to spend more on good quality.
So, what's to be done?
Cooper suggests that if we can afford it,
speaker: Neil

text: we really should try to buy higher quality products.
And manufacturers should put labels on their products,
saying how long they're designed to last.
An interesting idea.
Cooper says that over two million pounds worth of electrical goods
are thrown away each year in the UK.
He calls it a throw away culture.
A culture in which we throw things out much more easily.
speaker: Neil

text: Not good for the planet either.
So, will you try to keep your mobile for a bit longer
or are you already tempted by the latest model, Catherine?
I'm happy with the one I've got,
but I'm going to protect the screen very carefully.
Yes, a good idea.
speaker: Neil

text: Maybe this will help you make up your mind, though.
I asked how many tons of electrical waste are thrown away globally?
And I said I know the answer.
It's actually 42 million tons,
according to a UN report back in 2015.
The figure could be a lot higher now.
And as you know, my mobile isn't very heavy,
so 42 million tons is an awful lot of phones.
While we try to picture that,
let's quickly run through today's vocabulary.
So, first up was Gizmo,
a small piece of technology, a gadget.
Smart phones, smart watches,
fitness trackers, satnav's, or gizmos.
We had sustainable, able to last or continue.
speaker: gizmos

text: We talk about sustainable energy,
sustainable economic development.
The opposite would be unsustainable developmentâ€¦
speaker: unsustainable screwunscrew

text: And another pair of words to screw and to unscrew.
A screw is that little metal thing,
like a nail, that we used to join things together.
You can screw shelves into the wall,
you can screw furniture together.
And when you move house you unscrew it.
speaker: unscrew lower your expectations

text: Three more to lower your expectations.
What have you lowered your expectations about?
So many things.
Becoming a millionaire, I don't think that's going to happen.
Or I could say, a company has lowered his expectations
about performance over the next five years.
Yes â€“ another one looking ahead into the future
speaker: obsolete

text: I'm pretty sure my computer will be obsolete in 10 years.
It will no longer be used.
It will be out of date.
I just urge you, Neil, when you do get a new one,
please recycle this one responsibly.
We already live in a throwaway culture.
Yes â€“ it's pretty unsustainable
speaker: unsustainableobsolete

text: Now, before your laptop or phone becomes obsolete,
I suggest you check out our Facebook, Twitter, Instagram
and YouTube pages.
Bye for now.
Bye.
